You have advised us that you are purchasing this property as a home for you and your family to live in . 
We have highlighted in this report on title issues relevant to this purpose but you need to be aware of the following - 

	We have not visited the property and there will be things that the conveyancing process will not reveal. There is no substitute for you inspecting the property before contracts are exchanged to identify - 
a)	The state and condition of the property remember you buy the property as it stands and the seller does not guarantee or provide any form of warranty as to the state and condition of the property.
b)	Although it may be possible to sue the seller for misrepresentation if any of the information provided by the seller within the TA forms is incorrect compensation is only likely to be awarded if you commence proceedings against the sellers which will be a slow and expensive process and there is no guarantee of success. It is best to use the questions contained in the TA6 form provided by the seller as a checklist to satisfy your self as to the answers to the questions posed.
c)	Anyone in occupation of the property other than the sellers named in the contract. If someone is living in the property who is not named in the contract as a seller your purchase of the property might be subject to that persons right of occupation. You must let us know if you become aware of anyone who is in occupation.
d)	You must check the boundaries to your new property . We have provided you with a title plan (which you cannot rely upon), the estate agents particulars, the description of the property from the contract and the description of the property in the property register (within the official copies of the register).

It is worth walking around the area where your property is situated, familiarising your self with the area as well as the property . We recommend you look at access roads, neighbouring properties, the boundaries, the land and gardens, and of course the property itself. 
We have also recommended that you obtain a professional survey. 
We are not able to advise you on the value of the property nor of the commerciality of the transaction. We recommend that your surveyor or valuer sees this report in case there are any issues in this report that will impact on valuation. 

We are not able to advise you as to the location of any underground media conveying services to your property except where information provided by the seller in the TA forms and or in the replies to the drainage and water search. 
If you are concerned about the location of services you can make your own enquiries or you can instruct us to make  enquiries so as to locate those services. There will be additional costs if we are asked to do any additional work.
Please read everything that is contained in this report as all the issues we are drawing to your attention are important. If you have any questions or issues please let us know immediately because once contracts are exchanged it will not be possible to withdraw from the contract or to renegotiate the terms of the transaction and you will be bound to complete on the day agreed for completion.

A wall or fence standing on the boundary line between two properties will generally be a party wall or party fence, owned jointly, but if it stands wholly on one side or the other of that line it will belong to the owner of the land on that side. In the absence of specific information, if all supporting posts or structures for a wall or fence are on one side of it then the wall or fence will usually be assumed to belong wholly to the owner of the land on that side.

Answers.Text: Even if the deeds state that a wall or fence is the responsibility of a particular owner, a neighbour may not have the legal right to compel him to repair or maintain it. InformationList.Text: Info for - OBLIGATIONS - ADVICE TO CLIENTS

Answers.Text: Obligations can be imposed on buyers of land and buildings which will bind them and, usually, successive owners. Legal documents usually refer to these obligations as covenants'.

With regard to the easements revealed by an examination of the Sellers title  
You will be solely responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of the road,footpath,drain pipe, or service media referred to.
You will be jointly responsible for  the upkeep and maintenance of the road, footpath, drain pipe, or service media referred to.
The owner of the land with the benefit of the easement will be responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of the road, footpath, drain pipe, or service media referred to.

The title to your new  responsibility to make a contribution towards upkeep, repair, and maintenance is contained in. a rentcharge referred to in the title and protected by a notice in the charges register. This means that although you are not directly responsible for  the cost upkeep, repair and maintenance the rentcharge owner can ask you to contribute to that cost. We have (have not been)  not been provided with an estimate of the likely costs. Your title refers to the fact that the rent charge owner can charge a reasonable sum and can apportion costs incurred at its discretion. Non payment of a rentcharge whether demanded by the rentcharge owner or not can lead to enforcement action by the rentcharge owner leading to liability for costs frequently far in excess of the actual rentcharge payment. You must ensure you are made aware of the rentcharge required and that you pay the amount due in the time required by the rentcharge owner.

Paragraphs.Name: take action for breached covenant advice

Answers.Text: In connection with the covenants that benefit the Property it is important to understand that if you become aware that there is an attempted or actual breach of the covenant or steps are being undertaken to prepare to breach the covenant then you must react quickly and take action by either advising the relevant landowner not to breach the covenant or to take legal proceedings. A failure to act when a covenant is about to be breached or is being breached can prevent enforcement action being taken and an injunction stopping the breach being obtained.

InformationList.Text: Info for -  ADVICE TO CLIENTS ABOUT OBLIGATIONS

Purchase of additional items:  If you are purchasing any separate items, it is entirely up to you as to whether or not you wish their purchase to form part of the Contract or whether you wish to deal with the same privately with the Seller.  If to form part of the Contract we would, of course, be expected to pay over the money for the items on completion.

Generally the Seller has no duty to disclose to you the existence of physical Property. You must rely on your surveyor or valuer to carry out an inspection and to check, for example, that there is no evidence of alterations which might affect the structural integrity of the Property.

An EPC contains:
information about a propertys energy use and typical energy costs
recommendations about how to reduce energy use and save money
An EPC gives a property an energy efficiency rating from A (most efficient) to G (least efficient) and is valid for 10 years.


The first page of your EPC starts with an estimate of the current and potential energy bills of the property. This is useful for knowing how much a new property will cost to run in energy bills, as well as how much lower the running costs could be if the energy efficiency was improved.
hese costs are just for your heating, hot water and lighting. The EPC doesnt include any additional energy costs from your home appliances(such as the cost of running your fridge, oven, TV) so in reality your energy bills will be a bit higher. However, the costs shown can help you compare properties and see which building could be cheaper to run.


he next table you see on page one is a quick visual comparison of property performance similar to the energy labels you get on home appliances. Your property has a current energy efficiency rating. These range from A-G, with A being the best. Some EPCs also have a similar chart for a propertys environmental performance.

It also shows the potential rating if you carry out all the suggested improvements. In this example, you can see that the home could jump from band F to B with the recommended energy efficiency upgrades.

Performance -  gives you a detailed breakdown of each element of your property, with a description and an energy rating from one to five stars (with five being the best) to help you understand the effectiveness of its construction, heating and hot water system, and lighting. 

"Heat Demand -  looks at how much heat youre expected to use in the property and how you can reduce that by improving the insulation.
This is used to calculate Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) payments, so is helpful if youre considering renewable heating options."


"Recommendations - Here you get a detailed breakdown of the recommended measures, costs, savings and how much each measure could improve the propertys energy efficiency rating.

The recommended measures are shown in order of importance, and the energy efficiency improvements figures are based on making the improvements in that order. Of course, you might not be able to complete them all, or in the order listed, but its a good guide.

The number of recommended measures will vary, depending on which ones are applicable to your property. In this example, the first priority is wall insulation, and if the homeowner is really committed to bringing the rating up to B, the checklist ends with the installation of solar PV panels."

A copy of the EPC and the recommendation report for this Property is attached at Attachment 5 and the Property has a rating of [insert details ]. We are not qualified to advise on the energy efficiency of the Property but can pass on any queries you may have to the Seller.

All domestic and commercial buildings in the UK available to buy or rent must have an energy performance certificate (EPC), giving the property an energy efficiency rating from A (very efficient) to G (inefficient). EPCs are intended to give an indication of how costly it will be to heat and light a property and its likely carbon dioxide emissions. An EPC is accompanied by a report recommending any cost-effective improvements that might be made to the property to achieve a better rating.

The form of agreement for sale, referred to as the Contract document is in a standard form that the parties are required to utilise due to the Conveyancing Protocol. 
It might be necessary for the conveyancers for the seller or ourselves to amend the contract in readiness for exchange. If any amendments are made we will make you aware of them before contracts are exchanged. Sometimes those amendments will be handwritten but nonetheless we will  endeavour to obtain an unmarked/clean Contract from the Sellers lawyers incorporating all the amendments, but this is not always possible and the document sent to the client will often be the original amended and approved Contract. 
If the  Contract is not in the pristine condition you would expect it is still a valid legal document and, once it is signed and exchanged, it is fully enforceable.
The Contract is included with this Report on Title and we would be grateful if you could sign the contract in the place marked and return it to us. You will not be bound by signing the contract as we will hold it on file until it is safe to exchange and until you authorise us to exchange on your behalf.

The property you wish to purchase is described in the particulars on the first page of the enclosed Contract. You will see that the Contract is subject to a set of Standard Conditions of Sale. These   conditions are produced by the Law Society and  define the rights of the parties and govern the process from exchange of contracts onwards.

The Standard Conditions of Sale have been checked through by us and we consider these to create a fair balance between the interests of the Buyer and the Seller and acceptable for the use in this transaction.
The standard conditions of sale require you to insure the property upon exchange of contracts .

Paragraphs.Name: insure before exchange to check for claims

Answers.Text: Irrespective of what sort of buildings insurance is appropriate to your transaction, we would strongly advise you to make some enquiries about insuring the property before contracts are exchanged. The reason that we mention this is that insurance companies hold huge databases of information about area-specific insurance claims. You may not be aware of any particular issue about the property that you are intending to buy that would cause insurance premiums to be loaded, or even for an insurance proposal to be turned down in respect of the property. Accordingly, it is always sensible to make some insurance enquiries before you commit to exchanging contracts so that any such issues will be known to you before you have committed yourself to purchasing the property.

It is essential that you make full disclosure of any risks that we have identified to your proposed insurer of the property prior to exchange of contracts. If you are obtaining a mortgage either now or in the future, you must obtain insurance under normal terms.
All risks pass to you on exchange of contracts, so you must be sure that you are prepared for any eventuality.  We would strongly advise you to check now that you can obtain buildings insurance on reasonable terms and for a reasonable premium.
We would be grateful if you could provide us with a copy of the policy schedule prior to completion so that we can ensure this complies with your lender's requirements.
You are responsible for buildings insurance from exchange, and you must ensure that you maintain the correct level of buildings insurance during the lifetime of your mortgage. It is a condition of your mortgage that you do this, and you will be in breach if you allow the insurance to lapse or cancel it.

The Seller sells with Full Title Guarantee. This means that the Seller has good title to the property.

A full guarantee means that the seller warrants   - 
a)	To have the right to dispose of the property.
b)	At  own cost do all that reasonably can be done to give you the buyer the title purported to be given in the contract. This means that the seller 
c)	To dispose of the whole interest to you where that interest is registered.
d)	 That the seller is disposing of the property free from all charges and encumbrances (whether monetary or not) and from all other rights exercisable by third parties , not being rights which the seller does not and could not reasonably be expected to know about.

The Seller sells with Limited title guarantee. This means that the Seller is not able to offer a full guarantee and the warranties listed above are provided by the seller except that warranty d) is amended as follows - 
The Seller has not charged or encumbered the property by a charge or encumbrance which still exists , that he has not granted any third party rights which still subsist and that he is not aware that anyone else has done so since the last disposition for value. 
This means that the seller warrants that he has not encumbered the property but he does not warrant that his predecessor has not done so.
The Seller sells without any title guarantee. This means that Seller is not giving any warranties as to the title to the property.

A breach of title guarantee would enable you as buyer to sue the seller for breach of contract if there is a problem with your title after completion . If proceedings were brought by you against the Seller you would be required to meet the legal costs incurred. If your claim was successful you will be able to recover some of those costs and would also be awarded damages representing any loss you sustain.  It is always impossible to guarantee success if court proceedings are brought.

The basic principle in conveyancing transaction is let the buyer beware meaning that you buy the property as it stands. If it is defective you cannot bring a claim against the seller.

We advise that you obtain the best survey you can afford . Whilst the bank or building society will obtain a valuation the valuer is concerned with whether the property is adequate security for the loan the lender is providing.

There are three types of survey

This is recommended where you are buying, selling or living in a conventional house, flat or bungalow built from common building materials and in good condition.

The report concentrates on the condition of the property by setting out the following:
A traffic light ratings of the condition of different parts of the building, services, garage and outbuildings, showing problems that require varying degrees of attention
A summary of risk relating to the condition of the building; and other matters including guarantees, planning and building control issues for your legal advisers.

This report does not include a valuation, but the surveyor may be able to provide this as a separate extra service.

This report is appropriate where more extensive information is required when  buying a conventional house, flat or bungalow, built from common building materials and
in reasonable condition. The report includes information including :
 all of the features in the Condition Report plus a more extensive inspection
 the surveyors professional opinion on the Market Value of the property
 an insurance reinstatement figure for the property
 a list of problems that the surveyor considers may affect the value of the property
 advice on repairs and ongoing maintenance
 issues that need to be investigated to prevent serious damage or dangerous conditions
 legal issues that need to be addressed before completing your conveyancing and
 information on location, local environment and the recorded energy efficiency.

This report is appropriate if the purchase is of a large, older or run-down property, a building that is unusual or altered, or if youre planning major works. It costs more than the other RICS reports because it gives detailed information about the structure and fabric of the property.  The report will include the following information -
  
      a thorough inspection and detailed report on a wider range of issues
      a description of visible defects and potential problems caused by hidden flaws
      an outline of repair options
      the likely consequences of inactivity
      advice for your legal advisers and details of serious risks and dangerous conditions.
An RICS Building Survey does not include a valuation, but your surveyor may be able to provide this as a separate extra service. Estimated costs of repairs may also be included as an option.

Paragraphs.Name: Meaning of maintainable at the public expense

Answers.Text:
If a road, footpath, or footway is maintainable at the public expense you will not be obliged to contribute towards the cost of repair or maintenance of the road, footpath or footway unless the obligation is registered as a local land charge.
If a road, footpath, or footway is not maintainable at the public expense you may be required to pay all of the costs incurred for repair and maintenance.
Where the road, footpath, or footway is not maintainable at the public expense the local authority can resolve to make the road, footpath or footway up to a suitable standard and then maintain it at the public expense. In this situation you could be required to be liable for the costs incurred in making the road, footpath or footway up to the required standard
The roads, footways, and footpaths are adopted which means you and your visitors can use them as a means of gaining access to and from your property.
The roads, footways, and footpaths are not adopted which means you and your visitors cannot use them as a means of gaining access to and from your property

There are two additional problems in that an injunction for the alteration or the removal of the work that breaches the Building Regulations could be obtained outside this twelve month time limit and the local authority can prosecute the breach in the Magistrates Court where works were undertaken for a period of ten years.

If Building Regulation consent was required but was not obtained we can ask the seller to obtain a Regularisation Certificate or it is possible to obtain an indemnity policy to protect against prosecution or the local authority seeking an injunction.

The Community Infrastructure Levy is a discretionary planning charge that may be set by local planning authorities and is designed to assist in the funding of local infrastructure identified in a development plan. When a development has commenced and the liability to pay is triggered the levy is registered as a local land charge.

The Local Planning Authority as a collecting authority are responsible for the enforcement of debts and breaches of payment of Community Infrastructure Levy via enforcement action. That enforcement action can include asset seizure, the imposition of surcharges, charging interest, the issue of a Community Infrastructure Levy stop notice, and the potential for committal to prison.

A stop notice will stop development until the Community Infrastructure Levy is paid or the notice is withdrawn.

Enforcement action can be taken against the property owner. As a result it is important to determine whether there is any outstanding liability which needs to be discharged before completion.

Paragraphs.Name: Location of Sewers and Water Mains

Answers.Text:
The Drainage and Water search shows the location of the nearest water main and public sewer to the property. It does not show the route of any private supply pipe or drain connecting your property to the main service. You need to be aware that many Drainage and Water searches will now contain a qualification to the reply regarding public sewers within the boundary of the property that  from 1 October 2011 there may be additional public sewers, disposal mains or lateral drains which are not recorded on the public sewer map which may further prevent or restrict development at the property. This is due to shared drains which were private prior to 1 July 2011 becoming public sewers on 1 October 2011. The legislation related to all shared private drains (which, prior to that date, were of no concern to Water Authorities). Whilst these drains are now public sewers, the Water Companies do not necessarily know where they are, and it may be a long time before the Water Companys sewer plan incorporates the drains which became public sewers on 1 October 2011.
It is important to know where public sewers are within the boundaries of the property are located for a numerous  reasons:
	Because the Water Company has the right to enter the property to carry out works on the sewer, which may mean digging it up. (In practice nowadays, it is usually possible for the Water Companies to carry out works on sewers using remote controlled machines which avoid the need for digging up sewers.)
	The position of the sewer may restrict any future development at the property. One cannot simply build over the top of a public sewer or even very close to it. If one wants to build over or in the vicinity of a public sewer, then it may be necessary to obtain a Build Over Agreement from the Water Company. This has cost consequences both in terms of the cost of obtaining the agreement, and in as much as the terms of the Build Over Agreement may well specify that the works are carried out in a manner that would be significantly more costly than if the sewer were not there.

Where you are considering the possibility of extending or developing the property you should arrange a specialist drainage survey and seek the drainage engineer's advice as to whether your plans to extend or develop would be affected by the requirement to obtain a Build Over Agreement in respect of any extension or development within three metres of the public sewer.

Paragraphs.Name: Changes to Private Sewer Ownership in October 2011

Answers.Text:
The question of both ownership and repair of private sewers has caused problems with properties where there is a length of shared private sewer between the property and the public main.   However, from 1 October 2011, legislation meant that the Water Companies took over responsibility for some sewer pipes that previously belonged to homeowners.   A guidance note prepared by Discover Water concerning private sewer ownership and the changes that took place in October 2011 can be found at http://www.water.org.uk (at the publications section).  You should read this carefully.

It is important to understand that most properties are connected to mains drainage via a certain amount of private drain.  Since the changes to regulations concerning public sewers in 2011, the extent of the private drain for which a householder will be responsible will only be the section of drain exclusively used by the property within the boundaries of the property up to the point where it joins a shared drain.  Unfortunately, it is not easy to know exactly how long that piece of drain is and, since changes to regulations concerning the adoption of shared drains that took place in October 2011, the drain maps on Drainage and Water searches are often not reliable in that they only show what the Water Companies knew to be public sewers prior to 1 October 2011.  We fear that it will be a long time before the Water Companies update plans to include all of the shared drains and lateral pipes which became public sewers in October 2011.  

Water Companies will not know where the new public sewers are located, and the Drains and Water searches will have to be read accordingly. It seems likely that there will now be many public sewers that were built over before they became public sewers. The current view seems to be that Water Companies will probably be reasonably relaxed about the lack of a Build Over Agreement provided that any relevant Building Regulation consent required for building over a private drain was obtained.

Paragraphs.Name: Extensions built over sewers prior to October 2011

Answers.Text:
If the property was extended before 1 October 2011, we recommend your seeking advice from your surveyor or drainage engineer as to whether the extension has been built over a drain which prior to 1 October 2011 was a private drain but post 1 October 2011 has become a public sewer. While the Water Authority in such circumstances would be required to pay the cost of any works (including the demolition and rebuild of part or all of an extension), you should consider the practical implications and inconvenience which would be involved should such works be required.
We advise you to check with your surveyor if any extension appears to have been built prior to 1 October 2011 and let us know.

Paragraphs.Name: Extensions built over sewers after October 2011

Answers.Text:
Where an extension has been built over a public sewer since 1 October 2011 without a Build Over Agreement, the cost of any works required by the Water Authority, including demolition of an extension or re-routing of the sewer, would not be met by the Water Authority but would be your responsibility without recourse to any compensation either for the cost of the works or any consequent loss in value of the property.

As result of this we  advise that if an extension has been built since 1 October 2011 without a Build Over Agreement you should obtain a drainage engineer's advice as to the route of the drains and sewers serving the property, the distance of the drains and sewers from the extension or development and which drains are private and which are public sewers.

At present, it is necessary to be quite careful about ascertaining the status of drains built after 1 July 2011 which have not been the subject of an Adoption Agreement. These drains will, for the time being, remain private and the cost of such drains will fall to the property owners for repair and maintenance. We anticipate that there may be some difficulties in ascertaining the status of drains on large building developments where not all of the properties sharing private drains had been connected on 1 July 2011.

The Drainage and Water search includes comments about water quality which  might show that a property failed to meet required standards during tests in the area in the previous twelve months.  We are not able to give any guidance upon these test results.

 Water Companies may make random tests of water quality within houses.  Quite often, we understand, the reason for a failure of such a test may be nothing more than a dirty tap in the house where the test was made.  We are advised that the occasional failed test should not be cause for great alarm.

As you will see from the water and drainage search, water charges are based on rateable values rather than on metered supply.    It is our understanding that there is an intention by Water Authorities to eventually meter all properties rather than charge for water supply and drainage on the basis of rates.    Some Water Authorities are adopting a programme of rolling installation of meters and this is sometimes triggered by a change of ownership of a property.

SectionGroups.Name: Miscellaneous Issues in readiness for exchange

Answers.Text:
The completion date is the date on which the Contract will be completed. This is the date on which the buyer is expected to pay the balance of the purchase monies and also to move and gain possession of the property they are buying. 
As the transfer of the balance of the monies can only take place on a day when banks are open and willing to undertake the funds transfer, this means that completion (and therefore the moving date) must take place on a working day and cannot take place at a weekend or on a bank holiday or public holiday.
It is important that you recognise that there are two parts to completion:
(a) legal completion: involving the transfer of funds and receipt by sellers conveyancer; and
(b) practical completion: checking the property has vacant possession and is empty, and collection of keys by you.

On the day of completion, monies are transmitted throughout the chain by means of direct credit transfer from one Solicitors Bank to another. This method is referred to as a CHAPS transfer. Once a Solicitor has instructed the Bank to transfer the funds, the matter is entirely in the hands of the Bank and the Solicitor has no control over when the funds are actually sent or when they are received. It is not until the funds are received that keys will be released and that the transaction is considered completed.

In most cases, the system works very well but there are occasions when problems arise with the banking system and the transmission of funds is delayed. This will have a knock-on effect throughout the chain and can result in claims for interest and damages. Because the Banks will only guarantee credit of funds by close of business, they will accept no liability for any losses or claims arising as a result of the funds being received outside the contractual completion time. You will be responsible for any such claims or losses.
We must stress that once we have released funds into the system, we are totally reliant on the Banking system and cannot be held liable for the consequences of any delays that occur.

IMPORTANT: You may be aware that there has been a significant rise in fraudsters hacking emails from solicitors to clients and changing bank account details to divert completion monies into the fraudsters own bank account. If you have received this Report from us electronically, DO NOT send funds to the account details provided without first speaking with either the fee-earner who sent this Report to you or to our Accounts Department, making sure that you dial a number shown on our letterhead.

You are buying your property as co-owners. You have completed a co-ownership questionnaire and advised us that you would like to own the property as joint tenants, tenants in common in equal shares, tenants in common in unequal shares with the beneficial interest held (insert relevant proportions.

Remember if you own the property as joint tenants you own the beneficial interest equally and if one of you dies before the other the survivor automatically inherits the deceased share (known and survivorship.

If you own the property as tenants in common and one of you dies your share passes to whoever you have decided to gift your share to in your will or will pass to your next of kin under the intestacy rules.

Please be aware that a joint tenancy can be unilaterally severed creating a tenancy in common in equal shares. We have already provided advice as to the process involved. Also be aware that if a tenancy in common is to be created it is important to have a deed of trust prepared which deals with the operation of the trust and remember to keep the deed of trust under review if ownership of the beneficial interest or your circumstances change. We refer again to the written advice we have already provided concerning deeds of trust.

Property may be owned jointly either in separate shares (which the owners can bequeath separately in their wills or, in the absence of a will, will pass to their relatives under the intestacy rules) or on the basis of survivorship (where, on the death of one owner , the property passes automatically to the surviving joint owner or owners).  The law calls these respectively owning as tenants in common or joint tenants, although it has nothing to do with actual tenancies and applied even if the property is freehold.

If there are two or more buyers purchasing a property together please tell us whether you wish to buy the property in separate shares (and if so whether you are to have equal shares or other specified proportions) or on the basis of survivorship. [Where joint purchasers are not married or are not civil partners it is generally prudent for them to purchase in separate shares]. [Some couples buy property in separate shares as part of an inheritance tax strategy]. [There are important considerations regarding distribution of funds following sale where separate shares are held and it may be appropriate to enter now into a suitable deed of trust . Please tell us if you would like to us to advise further on this].

Where a property is initially bought on the basis of survivorship , it is possible for any one of the owners to change this later to separate shares just by giving written notice to the other or others. Where a property is bought in separate shares , it is possible by written agreement to change the proportions of ownership.

Before contracts are exchanged you will need to check that your available financial resources [and the net amount of any new loans] [and the sale proceeds of your existing property, less any outstanding secured loans and the sale costs] will be sufficient to pay the whole Purchase Price and all SDLT, registration charges and professional fees. 
Please remember that the fees that we and surveyors charge carry VAT at 20%. Please ensure that all your financial arrangements are finalised before instructing us to exchange contracts.

Paragraphs.Name: Four weeks between exchange and completion

Answers.Text: When agreeing a completion date with the Seller, please do not agree a period less than four weeks from exchange without checking with us that there is adequate time for us to deal with pre-completion legal matters [such as dealing with your mortgagees].

We will need your confirmation that you are happy to exchange contracts. You need to check that you have the appropriate finances to fund the purchase including the SDLT, Land Registry fees , and our professional fees. We have provided you with a completion statement showing the amount due from you.

Of course we will also require from you before we exchange contracts the ten per cent deposit as the contract requires. All financial arrangements need to be arranged by you and in place before instructing us to exchange contracts.

You should also arrange with the seller and or the estate agent the date you would like to complete and notify us  in readiness for exchange . Please let us know the date before you finalise anything so we can confirm that the proposed date is acceptable to us.

[Insert details]

We have already provided you with details of the policy . 

It is important you are aware of the following  

The level of indemnity for the policy is [insert the amount] This is an arbitrary sum which may not represent the loss you could sustain in the event of a claim. 

The policy imposes obligations and responsibilities on you including the duty to report any claims or any information that is relevant to the policy. It is vital that you notify your insurer about anything communicated to you about the defect in title as soon as you receive it. 

In addition it is very important not to disclose the existence of the policy to anyone other than your solicitor or conveyancer when you come to sell the property. Disclosing the existence of the policy is likely to invalidate it. 

Please ensure you read the policy and any additional information including our explanation of the need for the policy and our explanation of the terms and conditions of the policy . 


The defect in title remains but the existence of a valid defective title insurance policy should protect you and the lender during your ownership of the property.
